Aww man. Was hoping for a drawing of Teemo. :( 

More seriously, I understand your frustration.  The problem boils down to the following: for every unique technical question, there are probably only a handful of people who could give you a satisfying (and accurate) response, whereas everyone at Riot is interested and qualified to talk about people's yearbook quotes, Florida league players, etc.  

This problem becomes even trickier because many Rioters want to be of assistance but don't know the whole story.  Let's take your link, for example. It shows a Teambuilder game from two months ago (found it through scrolling through op.gg).  Now, because two months have passed, and we see that many of those sub-30 players are now Gold and Platinum (very, very good players), we can pretty safely assume that they were smurfs or savants.  However, to go beyond that line of assumption would be pretty fruitless.  I have no extra insider information on how matchmaking works, particularly not for Teambuilder. And this is why I generally don't reply to posts that I don't have extra info. on: because I sadly haven't told you anything you couldn't decipher on your own.

Whether they are working on the game or not has nothing to do with random Rioters commenting on our threads. Threads like what you want addressed have been addressed a thousand times already, yet people keep posting it as if they think they're the only one who brought the issue up, and that they need a personalized response. It's easier for Riot to just ignore them and keep working. If you can't see that, it's a fault in your own reasoning, not Riot's work.

You seem to be missing the point here.  Riot consistently bills itself as aspiring to be **The Most Player-Focused Game Company in the World**.  The following comment you made is completely in opposition to this ideal:

>It's easier for Riot to just ignore them and keep working.

I understand the mentality, I really do.  We should not be bothering with trying to regulate where or how Rioters post, it's not feasible nor is it something that would benefit the community.  That being said, it's a bit ridiculous to dismiss people's comments as being irrelevant just because an alternative is easier.  

The fact communication isn't resonating with the community is pretty important, regardless of what's easier for Riot.  Technically it would be easier for Riot if they never worked on improving the game, but that doesn't improve anything.

It's not their fault that you didn't browse the forums enough to find them. They often post extensive in-depth replies on Reddit, too. Sure, they could do a little better, but they aren't doing bad.

There is simply not enough time in the day to find each post, find the right person who knows what they're talking about, and make a proper reply. There is no benefit for it, either. (this is besides the fact that the answers you're looking for are probably already out there somewhere)

You see a lot of "riot posting on cat video thread"; well, so what? They often post on their free time (and doesn't take much time anyway), and often that isn't the person you want telling you about upcoming balance changes **because they don't even work on the balance team**. You don't ask the electrician to do your plumbing, do you?

>It's not their fault that you didn't browse the forums enough to find them.  

Right...because all of the communication discussions over the years have just been misguided people that don't pay attention.  

I spend huge amounts of my time posting on the boards and reading through threads; there is a reasonably high amount of communication involving gameplay, but very little involving auxiliary features such as community programs, lore, and preemptive communication on things like change logs, current projects, etc.  I am particularly interested in looking at communication from the largest scale I can as an outsider, so I follow the Boards extremely closely whenever anything references player-developer communication.

>They often post extensive in-depth replies on Reddit, too.

Followed by Riot not linking any of these replies to the Boards.  I know the platforms are separate and Rioters can go wherever they please, but it's still questionable that important conversation happens on third party platforms when there's a first party platform designed from the ground up to facilitate that conversation.

>Sure, they could do a little better, but they aren't doing bad.

Which invalidates criticism?  Improvement can't happen unless people are passionate about making things better, and in cases like this it tends to come down to constructive criticism.

>I spend huge amounts of my time posting on the boards and reading through threads

I think maybe you should consider that this might be an addiction, and that you would do yourself a favor by taking a break from LoL and backseat game developing.
Constructive.  I'm happy to have a discussion with relevant topic points, but it seems we're getting a bit derailed here.
